The stimulus material below describes a qualitative study on smoking based on cognitive dissonance
theory. This theory suggests that people select and interpret information in ways that allow their beliefs to
fit their decisions and behaviours.

         Smoking is a habit that may lead to cancer. The aim of this qualitative study was to explore
         which strategies smokers use to avoid the psychological discomfort of knowing that smoking
         can be dangerous to their health.

         The female researcher was an ex-smoker who conducted the research herself. A purposive
    5    sample of six smokers (two females and four males, with a mean age of 29 years) was recruited
         through the researcher’s own social network. The selection criteria required participants to have
         smoked for at least five years and to have tried to quit at least twice without success.

         The participants were informed that the study was about smoking and problems in quitting. They
         were also told they could withdraw at any time. They each signed an informed consent form that
   10    included permission to record the interviews.

         The interview guide included questions that were closed and open-ended. Each interview
         was conducted for 45 minutes, on a one-to-one basis. The interviews were audio-recorded,
         transcribed, and analysed by the researcher herself. The participants were asked to check
         the transcripts and the researcher’s conclusions before publication of the final report. Another
   15    researcher checked the findings.

        The researcher identified several themes for not giving up smoking, for example:
        y Optimism: “I haven’t had any health problems so far and I doubt I will have any in the future.”
        y Discrediting research: “Research on the effects of smoking is probably exaggerating
          the dangers.”
   20   y Protection of self: “I will simply be too stressed if I don’t smoke.”

         The researcher concluded that the participants in her study were unable to quit smoking despite
         their desire to do so and avoided psychological discomfort using cognitive strategies.
